95727832492070978202311050501.text:
Patches of dense fog with near zero visibility continue. 

Conditions will slowly improve through the day, however, some areas will likely see fog redevelop once again tonight.

Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations.

If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

161927616134870876202311060501.parentName: City of Edmonton - St. Albert - Sherwood Park
161927616134870876202311060501.text:
Patches of dense fog with near zero visibility continue for outlying areas of Edmonton.

Conditions will slowly improve through the day, however, some areas may see fog redevelop again tonight.

Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations.

If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.

221307412554901638202311050502.text:
Near zero visibility in dense fog and freezing fog

When: Today and tonight.

Where: North Peace River District including Fort St. John, Alaskan Highway. South Peace River District including Dawson Creek and Cheywynd.

Hazard: Slippery surfaces due to ice accretion in areas of freezing fog.

Remarks: 

Atmospheric conditions are favourable for the development of dense fog. While the dense fog may lift temporarily this afternoon, it's expected to redevelop again this evening and persist overnight. For the South Peace River region, the most dense fog is expected mostly over northern sections.

Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility.

If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

819342381555632719202311060502.parentName: Bulkley Valley and the Lakes District
819342381555632719202311060502.text:
Areas of dense fog are expected or occurring.

When: Now through early this morning.

Where: Houston, Burns Lake, Highway 16.

Hazards: Areas of dense fog significantly reducing visibilities. For communities with temperatures dropping below freezing, slippery surfaces may result.

Remarks: Areas of fog have developed throughout the region and are expected to dissipate later this morning.

If travelling, be prepared for areas of near-zero visibility. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

63353255317686800202311060502.text:
Near zero visibility in dense fog.

When: This morning.

Where: North Columbia and Highway 5.

Remarks: 

Areas of dense fog have formed in low-lying areas and will persist through this morning.

Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations.

Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

2021370772021819895202311040503.text:
Heavy snow today with risk of freezing rain. 

Hazards: 
Snowfall accumulations near 15 cm.
Reduced visibility at times in heavy snow.

Timing: 
Tapering off this afternoon.

Discussion: 
Snow, heavy at times, may become mixed with or transition to ice pellets or freezing rain this morning. The mixed precipitation or snow will taper to periods of light snow or flurries this afternoon.

Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

1155536392021819895202311050503.text:
Heavy snowfall expected today.

Hazards: 
Snowfall accumulations near 15 cm.
Reduced visibility at times in heavy snow.

Timing: 
Ending tonight.

Discussion: 
Snow, heavy at times, will taper to periods of light snow or flurries tonight. Snow may also become mixed with or transition to ice pellets or freezing rain late this morning and this afternoon near Highway 11. Areas south of Timmins will likely see a transition to rain this afternoon before a change back to periods of light snow this evening.

Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow.

Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

945453411395160432202311060503.text:
Freezing rain late this morning.

Hazards:
A period of freezing rain leading to light ice accretion on some surfaces.

Timing:
Ending early this afternoon.

Discussion:
A period of freezing rain is expected late this morning before a changeover to rain early this afternoon.

Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become icy and slippery.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

91247633872096566202311060504.text:
Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected.

A low pressure system approaching from Ontario will bring moderate to heavy snow tonight and on Tuesday. Snow may be mixed with rain during the day on Tuesday.

Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions.

Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

1959206061393827135202311050504.text:
Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected.

A low pressure system approaching from Ontario will bring moderate to heavy snow over northwestern Quebec through Tuesday morning. The snow may be mixed with rain overnight tonight and on Tuesday.

Be prepared to adjust your driving with changing road conditions.

Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

parentName: Meadow Lake - Big River - Green Lake - Pierceland
The Battlefords - Unity - Maidstone - St. Walburg
194020554923132923202311050501.text:
Dense fog to persist tonight into Monday. 

Fog has settled over parts of southern Saskatchewan overnight.

The fog is not expected to lift in earnest until late Monday morning to Monday afternoon.

Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero.

If travelling, be prepared for areas of near-zero visibility. If visibility is reduced while driving, turn on your lights and maintain a safe following distance.

Fog advisories are issued when near zero visibilities in fog are expected or occurring.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

1127356951531934689202311030502.text:
Blizzard conditions with gusty winds and persistent visibility near zero in blowing snow are expected or occurring.

Hazards: Periods of strong winds and near-zero visibility in snow and blowing snow. Wind chill near minus 30.

Location: Dempster Highway.

Timespan: Tonight through Tuesday midday. Possibly re-developing late Wednesday.

Remarks: A ridge of high pressure has shifted and settled along the Yukon/NWT border and lighter winds are now expected today. The ridge will shift to the northeast later today as pressures fall over the southwest Yukon, with strong winds through the Richardson Mountains re-developing this evening. 

Strong winds will lead to blizzard conditions with severely reduced visibilities in blowing snow and dangerous wind chill values.

Winds are forecast to ease again near midday on Tuesday and possibly return late in the day on Wednesday.

Travel is expected to be extremely hazardous due to reduced visibility.

Prepare for quickly changing and deteriorating travel conditions.

Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@ec.gc.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
